Now that the game is fully released i can give a full review

Graphics - 6/10 by modern standards the graphics are quite poor, they chose to use directX 9 along with unity, The Graphics look ok at first but when you look closer you realise how basic they are.  Water looks terrible, no 3d grass for light rough and rough, lighting is very basic and the performance is inconsistant from course to course. I have to turn settings down on an I7 4790k@4.6ghz and a amd Fury to maintain 60fps on some courses.

Gameplay - 7/10 RTS is broken, it is way too sensitive, move the mouse back 2 pixels and thats a full back swing at 800dpi* on a 1080p screen, only increasing the screen to 1440p and the mouse DPI down to 400 is the RTS some what controlable,this is using the lowest sensitivity setting in game....

Even then there is no feel and putting is a joke, with the ball rocketing off the face after the smallest slowest movement you can possibly do with a mouse, to top this the game gives zero feedback whilst on the course has to what you are doing right or wrong, the only way to get feedback is to go to the practice area (no putting green btw), and you will get feedback through a launch monitor,  not that it will be any use to you as there is zero explination of what the numbers mean, so if you have never been on launch monitor in real life and had the number explained to you, you are screwed basically. This wasn't thought through at all and they listened to totally the wrong people when implementing this.

*Mice used Roccat Kone XTD and Corsair Vengence M65

However mouse swing using the meter isn't bad at all,  although it will be very difficult for the beginner. so max assists is recommended..

Presention - 6/10 simple menus very easy to navigate....nothing to write home about

Value - 5/10 Thought long and hard about this, if the game was £14.99 i would say yes the game is good value for what you get, but they have released it at £26.99...and on top of that have release an extra course as day one DLC (if you have DLC ready for day one, it should be in the game at no extra cost) and are planning more micro transactions.  So id say this game isn't good value, as of now there is no career or progression system, there is a planned course designer, but has yet to materialise (no idea what its going to be like)...there is online play, and solo rounds, for a golf enthusiast maybe just enough, but for a gamer looking for something to play, £26.99 is going to be poor value.

Overall 5/10 This game offers nothing for the causual/gamer player, the learning curve is very steep, with zero understandable feedback from the game ( A launch monitor is jibberish to the none enthusiast Golfer, even to some Serious golfers), The gameplay is kind of there, you just have to put is stupid amounts of hours to find it, and you will have to go on the forums to find out what the numbers on launch monitor mean....

I do like parts of this game, but i can not recommend it (not at £26.99), so its a thumbs down from me.

Early Access Review

Seriously guys,  I don't mean to be harsh,  but it's been along time since the launch of this gof game  and the game looks nothing like the original videos and screenshots that you presented us with before the game was released!

I remember viewing a spectacular video of a mountain course with a beautiful waterfall and stream and to be honest with you,  the graphics in those videos are on par with 'The Golf Club',  but 'Perfect Golf' doesn't look anything like the videos or screenshots that Parellel Perfect portrayed their game to be, even when you look at the three screenshots on their homepage the graphics are not as good in the game!

I am running the game on a 4k monitor at 3840x2160 using a Nvidia GTX 970 4GB OC and a i7 4970k @ 4.6Ghz with all the settings on high,  with the exception of changing the amount of trees in distance and detail.

I was an old Links LS fan who played the golf sim from the very beginning when the first version of Microsoft Links was released rouglhy 20 years ago,   and Mike Jones who is one of the founding owners of Perfect Parellel use to design and sell the best DLC courses for Links LS,  and incidentally I owned everyone of Mike's courses.

When I first came across the previews for 'Perfect Golf' and saw the screenshots,   I knew straight away it was Mike's work,  and I sent an email to him asking him about this new project.

I was extremely excited when Mike told me they were developing a new golf Sim for the PC similar to LinksLS,  and I was even more excited after viewing the screenshots on their website, as well as the amazing flyby video of a mountain course, and the actual hole had this amazing looking stream and waterfall, and the green sat on a small island!

However, so far I am personally very dissapointed with Perfect Golf,  and it's not just the visuals,  but the way the game plays as a simulation!

I'm sorry Mike,  even though it's still in developement,  it has taken far too long to produce a golf sim that's on par with 'The Golf Club',  and the reason my review is so harsh even though the game is still in development,  is simply because before the game was released,  the work in progress looked amazing, just like the screenshots and videos that are currently on your website.

If this work had already been developed,  how come the initial release didn't look as good as the pre developed work!

Personally I think it's deceitful and dishonest to place work in progress shots that look amazing on your website and on the Greenlight section of Steam to gather as many followers and potential buyers for the game,   and when you finally release the game,  it looks nothing like the preview screenshots and videos!

The performance of the game is fine,  but really, it looks and plays like a cheap game, and yes I'm aware that it's still in development,  but as I said,  the work in progress should've been implemented into the game by now!

The other important fact  is that eventually they will charge for additional courses and the course designer (Architect Application)!

Most people won't pay for additional courses,  when you have golf games like 'The Golf Club' that comes with the Greg Norman course designer and all courses a absolutely free!

However,  if the Jones's can make Perfect Golf look amazingly perfect,  hardcore golf Simmers like myself will pay for quality, especially if the courses are designed by Mike!

Perfect Golf should be perfect by now,  but it is far from being perfect!

If you guys at Perfect Parellel want to dominate the Golf Sim market,  you need to deliver what you originally presented ASAP,  before the interest dies off.

I won't give up on Mike and his team at Perfect Parellel,   simply because I know they have the potential to make the best Golf Sim on the market!

I will continue to check on the progress of  Perfect Golf from time to time to see if it does deliver what it was set out to in the first place!

Hopefully one day,  the visuals and the game play I saw on  Perfect Parallel's website will be implemented into 'Perfect Golf',  and it may very well become the perfect golf Simulator!

Product received for free

Jack Nicklaus Perfect Golf features, to borrow words from one of their devs/fanboys, quite possibly the worst communicated season/annual pass and microtransaction systems that I've ever seen.

Not once on any store front or this very page on Steam is it explained that the season pass is NOT for the majority of Steam gamers even though this is very clearly a Steam game. Players who enjoy the game and would consider the season pass on the basis that they want the next twelve months worth of content (an annual basis) are left to make the decision to pump $200-ish into the game without any knowledge that they wont get any benefit from it.

Steam users have become accustomed to purchasing season passes to their games that are detailed and communicated professionally to the point that that they know what they are going to receive for their money before purchase. They are not thrown into the deep end and face a high priced annual pass that they have little to no way of knowing what they are getting let alone whether the investment is the right one for them -- which it really isn't going to be for a significant percentage of your Steam player base. For those that do fit the bill, you're right, it is a bit of a bargain (ELI5 - other golfing simulation software that serves a very niche audience are generally priced in the vicinity of $1000+ and occasionally upwards of five times that so in effect the devs have made the market much more accessible).

Although I have had positive communication with ONE member of your team the others that have contacted me along with your fanboys have been quite aggressive. This aggressiveness has reached the point of almost being considered criminally abusive. I have personally elected not to respond in kind. In fact, I argue that silence in this instance is the appropriate response.

PERFECT PARALLEL, Your game may be one of the most playable golf sims on the market but your behavior and inexcusably woeful communication abilities are the overriding reason why the game suffers such a mediocre review score on Steam. Perhaps if you improved your communication skills your player base would have a much better idea - anything is better than none - of what they are actually criticizing you for. There's a reason why all but one of the most 'helpful' reviews of your game on the front page, as of writing, are thumbs down.

Early Access Review

I've played golf for over 25 years. Also, I've been playing the best golf-sim till now, the RTS swing in Links 2003. I thought it would be impossible to better that. Other games, like Tiger Woods, WGT or The Golf Club have lot's of glitch 'n glossy of course, but they don't have that 1 definitive thing: a true golf swing. It's just not there. And that is what a lot of people have been waiting for: the true dynamics that go with immerging yourself in a virtual golfing environment. Swing plane, swing tempo, clubface angles, it's all there. And more. Much more.

But it's here now! For the very first time, we now have 'The Motion Swing' in Perfect Golf. A true masterpiece of computer engineering. After spending a couple of hours on the driving range in PG, I've started mastering this great simulation. Everything is there, albeit in embryonic phase, not polished and glitchy yet, but it's there! AND it works beautifully. For every golfer out there, real or otherwise, Perfect Golf is going to be your game, I garantee it.

Once you get past The Motion Swing (3-click is also on board for the diehards) you'll discover courses and other options to keep you happy for ever. Not right now of course, the game is being build as I write this, but in the coming months PG is going to become the new standard in simulation golf. One reason for this, is because it has a man on board who has been at the forefront of golfcourse design: Mr Mike Jones. A one time golfpro himself, he started dabbling in PC golf years ago, and ultimately became a major force is this departement. It helps if you KNOW what the game is all about.

A sublime golf swing, real weather simulation, all kinds of gameplay, on- and offline, courses come to life with moving objects like trees, water etc, Perfect Golf is going to be everything golfing adepts have been waiting for. All we now have to do is wait for it's completion.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off, a big thanks to the devs on bringing us this Early Access version of Perfect Golf. I'm running the game in windowed mode 1280x768 on a 5 year old laptop with AA on and Bloom on. Trees are set at 350, shadows 200, Grass 100 and camera view distance 1500. All things considered the game runs good apart from a few stutters here and there that I can live with and haven't yet affected the playability.

Ball Physics: the team has done a wonderful job on the ball physics, especially after the latest update. I considered the ball physics in Links v1.07 to be one of the best I've seen in a golf game but in PG they've taken it to another level of realism. Sure, there is still some work to be done but having played a few different golf games this is the best I've experienced as yet .......

BUT .... while I feel that tee to green the devs have created up to now the best simulation of real golf yet seen in a computer game, I do feel an element of realism is then lost with the putting model. To help explain this I should point out I am a novice real life golfer, having only played the game for around 18 months. So it is fresh in my mind what it is like to be a beginner and having to learn the game. I feel a simulation should have the same sort of difficulties and learning curve with all aids off as the real thing. That may also mean I'll never be able to shoot under par for a round as in real life. A par on a hole should feel like an achievement. Unfortunately the putting model destroys this sense of achievement because it feels like I have too much help. Sometimes I misjudge my long putts on a real course massively - and that never seems to happen to me in PG due to the putting meter. And sometimes in real life I've putted from the fairway just off the green and given too much power and ended up off the other side of the green. I can't seem to do that in PG as my power is limited by the meter.

My suggestion - a straight swing bar that follows the movement of the mouse. The putter head placed two thirds down the bar with movement then for back swing and power and length of follow through for movement. Putting aids can be markings on the bar to help judge distance but true simulation mode with no aids would be with no markings and just from feel as in real golf. Don't know if something like this is possible. It would mean that by selecting a putter the graphic would automatically switch from an arcing swing meter to a straight putting bar. In simulation mode full back swing (of course restricted to a point) and full, fast follow through would always result in a maximum power putt.

A free roam mode would be nice, even if it was only restricted to a 20 or 30 yard zone around the golfers position, to allow for better planning of shots like in real golf when views are restricted. Of course, these restricted views should also be set to golfers eye level for realism.

Look forward to future update improvements and hopefully more courses. Great job so far and the closest to a simulation of the game I've yet to play.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game has huge potential and promise. Granted, the EA version has a few issues upon initial release but they are being caught by the new users and the Devs have a good list of things to work upon. That said, the game is beautifully playable offline and only limited today, by the online connections many games suffer from. It's best to begin offline anyway and play the game as it was made to be, a golf simulation. I wouldn't play a real golf course without learning how to hit a ball..!

The graphics on my 4yr old system run fine. I'd love to improve them, but to ensure the game runs with a good frame rate, I opted to keep the graphics down. However, the view is good, I have no tears or glitches and the screenshots I've taken look great. I can play the game at fullscreen in 1920 x 1080, so everything is as I expect.

Gameplay is almost spot on. It puts you in total control when playing using the 3 click system. The other control method is still being developed, so I'd expect that area to improve alot over the coming months. I won't comment any more on that, as I've not really tested it. This isn't like older or other golf games, it feels more Sim than Arcade. Granted it has a few elements that are needed to transfer anything simulated to a computer game, but they are minimal and necessary.

Real Time Weather is pretty cool, and works a treat. The Time of Day setting is one of my favourite things, being able to visually see the sun rising or setting, and playing a twilight game has the good old feel of those summer evenings, with time on your side.

Currently the 5 courses are just about right. With the promise of many more to come, it will soon become a tough decision choosing what course to entangle yourself within. Plus of course the Course Forge (Designer) a little further down the road.

I'd certainly like to see alot more improvements, walking the hole, first person perspective to name a basic few. However, reading the forums and discussions from the Dev's have made it clear these guys want to deliver something similar too. It feels like a winner to me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Terrible!

It's not a golf game, it's a shell of a golf game with no internals. There is no AI, no season/career options, no stats, no tournament play. You can play a round against yourself or an online opponent and that's it! Graphics are average but it does however still require serious PC juice to run. Menus are few because there are no real features that require menus. Visually the menus have a very simplistic layout and are certainly not intuitive to navigate. There are no great new features in Perfect Golf that other golf games don't have. The features it does have are nothing new and are extremely basic with many bugs/issues.

You would think the developers would do something great with one of the most important areas of any golf game, the swing meter! Well, no, it's as basic as you can get!
I like to click. You have some very basic difficulty settings you can adjust for the game difficulty and that's the end of the swing meter feature list. There is no option to change the swing meter speed to something of your liking. There is no option to add markers to the meter. The meter links to the graphics engine so if you don't have a silky smooth running game, you also won't have a silky smooth meter making it impossible to play. These are simple meter options golf games over a decade old provided. Perfect Golf gives you the most simplistic of meters with virtually no options to tailor it.
If you use the mouse method for swing, same deal, extremely basic with little to no control. There is not even a horizontal mouse swing option! There is no feedback on how well you did with your swing as in Tiger Woods games so you never know what area of your swing needs work.

Considering how little of a golf sim Perfect Golf provides, you would think the developers would nail what has been done before in golf games and improve upon those features. No such luck! Here we have first time developers and it shows in every bland detail of the game!

One final example to leave you with. The game contains a follow the ball in flight option same as a ball-cam from the Tiger Woods games. In Tiger Woods the camera follows the ball through flight and as it hits the ground the camera smoothly follows behind the ball as it bounces and comes to a stop. In Perfect Golf, as the ball hits the ground, the camera bounces along with the ball! The entire screen jumps up and down. Talk about annoying! Talk about motion sickness! Talk about the feeling you are playing arcade golf! You find youself expecting the golf ball to explode or some dude to come out from behind a tree and start shooting at you every time your shot hits the deck!

It's an early access game but it's not too difficult to see a game that no amount of time and patching will help ever become a good one. Complete waste of money and time!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hands down the best golf simulation ever created. Things that seperates itself from other games:

-A real time physics engine combined with real ball flight data(launch angles, spin rates and ball speeds) taken from launch monitors put this game in a class of it's own. Once you experience the before mentioned there really is no going back to other golf games.

-The Motion Swing mouse mechanic is a first of it's kind that introduces D plane swing theory. What is D plane theory and how does it realate to the mouse? Well, the simplified answer is the tracking of the actual swing path plus the tracking of the clubface angle. Your swing path is determined by the direction you move the mouse and the clubface angle is determined by the tempo at which you move your mouse.

-A real time weather and lighting system allow you to input a geographic location and play in those weather and lighting conditions. Never before has a golf game recreated weather and lighting conditions like this game. The lighting and shadow effects are exceptional and really change the look and feel of a course. You can even play in a thunder and lightning storm. Even though you wouldn't do this in real life it's worth doing in PG just to see the lightning effects.

-The last thing worth mentioning, and maybe the most important is, this may be the first game to offer up realistic scores in competition. I see no way to shoot in the 50's on a consistent basis, especially with aids turned off. I see scores being very close to real life, maybe even higher. Since tempo plays such a high role in the swing, straight edging or trying to zero out the x axis on the mouse is not going to get your far. Also, since the game uses a real time physics engine to determine spin you can't put artificial spin on the ball and throw darts at every flag.

$20 for this game is a steal. Buying it now will save you $10 to $15 when it goes retail. Once the course forge is released with the retail version and courses start pouring in, there will be no reason to even talk about another golf game. The potential this game has is limitless. If done right, this could be one of the greatest sports sims ever created.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been playing golf and computer games for about 25 years now, ever since I was about seven years old, so I feel reasonably qualified to comment on something that combines the two.

The early access of Perfect Golf is a fantastic start and the devs appear to have every motivation to bring the game to full fruition. Unlike many early access titles, the devs at Perfect Golf aren't promising heaven and earth just to get people's money but they are promising to create a great golf sim for real golfers, something I firmly believe they are very capable of delivering.

The current basic build is solid and enjoyable enough to hint at what is to come. Of course it has some bugs and it is missing many features and some areas require polish but these are all being identified and dealt with systematically and professionally as far as I can tell.

For anyone looking to buy this game in its current form, note that it does not yet have the following features which some may want to wait for:

- Computer opponents
- Career mode
- Golfer appearance customisation
- Statistics and Tracking

I would also say that, while the game looks very nice on my machine in ultra high detail at 1080p (you need a proper gaming graphics card here by the way), the golfer animation could be doing with being more fluid and the feeling more solid when the ball is struck or impacts the turf. It just feels a little floaty at this point with the golfer, terrain and ball all having a slightly disconnected feel. Additionally, the wind conditions seem to have no effect on the trees or flag; at 50mph the trees move identically to when the wind is at 10mph.

On the other hand, the in flight ball physics are awesome and the mouse control motionswing" mechanic is brilliant and is easily the closest feel to a real golf swing that I've experienced in a PC golf game. This mechanism puts the onus on the tempo and rhythm of your swing rather than just how straight you can move the mouse back and through (anyone remember table edging?). Ok so this game is pretty fun for a golf game. There are only a few concerns that i can bring up that they need to fix.
1. Sometimes you can get your ball to bounce out of a bunker and as far as I know, bunkers aren't trampolines.
2. Putting power and the power system. There is a a line that is what is the recommended strength for the the putt but it says you may have to adjust yourself based on the incline/decline of the putting green. This is false. If you go above the line on average putts it doesn't change the power at all. Same goes for if you go below the line. Chips and bunker shots have the same kind of wonky thing happening.
3. Wind. Wind seems to have little to no effect on the ball's trajectory even at 17-19 mph.
4. Your persons legs disappear when standing on an incline.
5. The in game sound is insanely loud, even when  you put everything at 4% of the 100% possible. For me, 1% is about perfect.
6. Ball spin. If you position the shot to where you get underneath the ball when you swing, backspin should accompany the shot as well as the shot going shorter than normal because it should increase the arc on the ball. No such thing happens. The ball goes farther and when it lands no backspin happens. Instead when you don't position it at all and just swing normally your ball will get this weird ghost backspin that happens for no reason. Topsin has a similar effect where the ball doesn't change trajectory at all other than it flys shorter than normal. No ball spin happens when it lands as well.

If they can touch up a few of these mechanics they have in the game but have no effect on it then this game will literally be perfect golf. Except for like, real golf...

Cons:
There still seems to be a lot room for growth in this title. Most of the things I would say need to be fixed have already been touched on by other reviewers. However, I would have to differ in my opinion of the severity of the negative comments. I think that the main areas that will help improve the quality of this release are more player customization options, refined motion swing meter / character interaction, and more courses(...CourseForge).

Overall, I am happy with the quality for such an early version of what has the potential to be an amazing golf game. Like I said, I am truly excited about the release of CourseForge, as I believe it will add a great deal of value to this release. I think that some people expect more from Early Access titles, and may be a little harsh on the developers. I hope that they will be able to take the feedback they are receiving, and turn this game into the next big thing in golf simulation software.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been playing Tiger Woods '08 PC on a regular basis since it came out back in 2007.  No modern golf game has come close.  That is until PerfectGolf was released.

The graphics are top notch and very realistic.  You can see all of the undulations and slopes on the fairways/greens very clearly unlike some golf games.  The addition of trees and bushes from SpeedTree last year improved the visuals a great deal.  The graphic improvements will no doubt continue in the future with the possible addition of 3D blades of grass using Nvidia’s Turf Effects tool.

The newly implemented Real Time Swing for controller and mouse has enhanced the game immeasurably in addition to the availability to download fine user made courses (around 24 available as of the date of this review).  That brings the current number of stock and user made courses up to around 37, a number no other modern golf game can touch.  These course numbers will continue to grow and grow once the CourseForge tool comes out and also once the developers start making licensed courses available.

Online play is great with turn based multiplayer and the ability to tee off with up to 8 players.  You can stop and resume your round at a later time.  There are loads of different play modes available in PerfectGolf.  If tournaments are your thing you can participate in many online as well as ones on onlinegolftour.net.  The game also has a cool replay feature that allows you to watch the last shot from a number of different angles.  Your opponent(s) can see the replays as well.

Another big plus for PerfectGolf is the freecam mode which allows you to more effectively read putts and scope out your next shot, even while your online opponent is getting ready to hit.  Take a virtual tour of the entire course from every conceivable angle and soak in the wonderful immersion that this game provides.

PerfectGolf has lived up to its potential as superb golf simulation.  Every update over the last year has shown improvement, especially the most recent update from last month.  This community driven game will only get better in the months and years to come.  Be sure to give it a try and you won't be disappointed.

I really like Perfect Golf. It has the look and feel of the PGA Championship PC game that I used to play, but Perfect Golf has the advantage of a strong and growing on-line capability thanks to STEAM. I have just several minor complaints about the game.

First, I wish that the wind was more of a factor in the game to make players think a little more about how to shape shots. Clever  players could then hit fades and draws on purpose to hold the ball against the wind, or use the wind more to move around dogleg corners depending on the situation.

Second, I don't believe that players are penalized enough when hitting into or out of the trees. I have seen many shots go right through the trees like they were thin air, when in real golf the tree limbs or leaves would have knocked the ball down. Fairway bunker shots also seem a little too easy compared to real golf.

Lastly, I suspect that some of the players out there that are using the Motion Plus method to swing the club are using a track or some other kind of aid to move their mouse perfectly each time. It's too much of a coincidence that they have the same shot shape everytime, especially when consistently hitting it with over 100% power. That creates an unfair advantage over those players who use the tri-click method. I recommend that you allow just the tri-click method for on-line play to guarantee that no player has an advantage over any other.

Updated review

Rating 1-10

Realism = 10
Graphics, physics and RTS and you feel like your on the course. Just set the difficulty level to match your real game or lower it to beat the real Pros. If your a masochist just play Tour Pro and Real time swing but be prepared to shoot a higher score then you do in real life. Graphics = 9.5
Color and textures are awesome, Other then walking out my back door to the course i believe it's as close as you can get.

Physics = 9
It has varied quite a bit over the updates and it's just getting better

Swing types = 10
Three click, Motion Swing is awesome, Real Time Swing just added and love it, it brings me to my real game of golf.

Game play = 6-9
Varies due to updates and working bugs out each update, which is pretty timely and usually the same day for a major bug on new update release day. Swing difficulty options are numerous and you can adjust as you progress. Career mode upcoming and Season of play at off sites (OnlineGolfTour.net). Community small but growing. Shift WASD Key for shot setup would be great one day. Icon next to player to verify swing type or filter to allow only certain swing types. Course Quality = 9
Colors and textures are very nice. Older end pc's may have some issues on Higher graphic settings.

Course Creation = 6
Just improved with last update and seem to be rolling out for user created courses of Beta Course Forge. Full release of Course Forge Pending and untried by me personally.

Player ANI = 6
Work in progress, clothing options just added. Equipment updates are in the works

Compared to other Golf games, the Best out there if you want the actual feel of playing golf in motion swing or Real Time Swing.

Early Access its a bargain and it's only getting better, for some it can be frustrating with updates and working through bug issues. For $20 my playtime in game is down to 1 cent per hour.

reviewText:
Jack Nicklaus Perfect Golf is what you play if you're looking for a realistic and challenging golf sim. This is the real deal.

The game can be as hard as you want it to be. Want to go easy on a flat green course using 3 point click on Beginner? Go for it. After a while, you'll birdie too often and want more of a challenge. No problem. There's Hacker, Amateur, Tour, and Tour Pro that'll challenge you further. These higher difficulties make swing timings more precise, resulting in shots more prone to shank if you're off just a bit. At the highest levels, you won't even be told the wind speed or direction and will have to rely on visual cues like the flag's movement. This says nothing of additional round settings like wind speeds (which can be set to weather forecasts), pin placements, green firmness, etc. You'll botch plenty of shots at first until you practice to get your swing down while you learn to master both courses and conditions. Just like in real golf.

Beyond that, there are different swing styles that change ball striking experience. Want to feel like you're actually swinging something on your PC without a gamepad? Motion Swing allows you to use your mouse as a club to swing. You'll have to literally swing back and forward both straight and within a backswing-to-forwardswing time frame ratio in order to hit your shot straight. If you have a controller, you can use joysticks.

This is a game with a great deal of depth and multiplayer replayability with a learning curve as steep as you make it. Still, the game launched a bit prematurely. The multiplayer lobby is quirky, at best; dysfunctional, at worst. Computer opponents are wildly inconsistent, too, so to play a decent opponent, you'll have to put up with the lobby's quirkiness or practice on your own.

In spite of all of this, if you're pleased enough with the gameplay, you'll be patient in waiting for patches to remedy the game's weaknesses.

There are negative reviews about season passes that are misinformed. These passes are for additional equipment you can buy to actually hit golf balls into a net and track their flight in-game, which seems like a pretty dang cool add-on if you ask me. The developers are in no way forcing customers to pay for the base game and a season pass to play for a year.

The store also offers additional courses to purchase—currently Bethesda for $4.99. There is unwarranted outcry about this as well because the game comes bundled with plenty of courses to keep the gameplay varied enough for a good while—14 full courses if my count is right, and 2 practice ranges. Offering additional DLC content to the core game is exactly what a lot of developers do these days. It's not in the base game, so therefore, you pay more for it. Sounds fair enough.

All in all, the strengths far outweigh the weaknesses. I do hope the developers continue to flesh out the kinks, but they've managed to produce a very solid game with gameplay that'll keep you coming back for more if the sort of golf sim you're looking for is both realistic and increasingly challenging. These two strengths make the game that much more rewarding and fun when you do get a handle on things and are able to be competitive against others in multiplayer matches.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Highly recommended.  A recent update added quite a few community made courses (along with updates to the stock courses in the game) and also added several new swing styles.

A wide range of swing styles are available:

Traditional 3-click with a power meter

Motion Swing with the mouse that has a meter on the screen (your choice of swinging horizontally or vertically)

Real Time Swing with the mouse (your choice of swinging horizontally or vertically.  No meter on the screen but the player animation moves in concert with the mouse movement)

Real Time Swing with a controller

The game can also be played on a home golf simulator.



The motion swings are my personal favorites.  Tempo has a large part in determining the outcome of the shot (as well as swing path and heel/toe hits)  so it's not as simple as straight back/straight through.  A truly wonderful way to play PC golf.


There are also a wide range of difficulty options so you can jump right in and enjoy the game.  The easier levels are a great introduction to the game.  Casual player or just want to have a fun round?  It's here.

The highest levels of difficulty are quite tough but it doesn't feel unfair or gimmicky.  If you can control your swing, you can still score well.  If you're not playing well, it can be a real grind, but  it is so rewarding when you put a good swing on the ball.  A great option for the hardcore sim player.

The course designs are beautiful and the ball physics are the best I've seen in a PC golf game.  A wide range of stimp settings are available for the green speeds, several firmness settings for the fairways, and several settings for pin positions.

Currently there are about 33 courses in the game, as well as a large driving range and a short game practice area.


The game is still in Early Access so things are still being worked on.  Things not yet included in the game but are planned for the future:

-Career mode

-Assortments of clothing/animations/clubheads/balls/shafts etc...

-Course building software

-More courses

-Improved AI for the CPU players

-Country clubs and tournaments


There currently is a REALLY good third party tournament site that hosts weekly tournaments for various skill levels as well as fun ancillary events.

They have an automatic scoring system set up that will keep track of your scores and stats after each round and maintains them on their site.  They also maintain different tours, world rankings, money leaders, ongoing season stats, etc.. and it's free to join.  A very well run tour.

http://onlinegolftour.net/index.html


I'm sure I'm forgetting some things but again, this is a great game.

Early Access Review

I'm recommending this game for what it is; a lot of others are reviewing it based on what it isn't (yet).

So what is it?  It's a golf sim.  It's targeted at people who want the feel of real golf.  Good physics, accurately rendered real courses, lots of camera options.

The game does lack a lot of features that modern gamers probably expect, career modes, avatar customisation, tee options etc.  But you have to keep in mind it's an indie title.  I'm not sure how big the development team is, but I doubt it's huge.  They've been making steady improvements and constantly provide informative feedback.  Progress has been slow, but the patient have been rewarded and they're getting close to a polished product as I write this.  Even those who have been hammering the developers with criticisms re: the physics are starting to quite down as adjustments are made.

There has been some controversy regarding the direction Perfect Parallel will take regarding a possible subscription service to play user made courses.  I too am concerned, but to give the game a thumbs down based on something that hasn't happened yet is unfair.

Ignore the 6/10 average.  As a fairly cheap Early Access game, it gets an 8 from me.  If you love your golf give it a go, get on the forums and help make it into something magnificent.

I have been waiting for a golf sim, and the early access of Perfect Golf seems to be headed in the right direction. Obviously, with an early access, there are things that are needed and things that are fine as is. So far, I can say confidently that the heart is beating in this game. Visually it's appealing and the game-play engine itself is a good start. Some of the issues at this point, I hesitate to mention, again because I suspect every feature and tweak I would like to see has been accounted for by the developers and they are working on it. That being said:

The menus need work and making changes to the settings on the fly is clunky. The types of shots are limited at the moment and needs attention, as does the power meter and putting helpers. Right now, they don't really make much sense and seem arbitrary. There's no way to punch shots through or accurately alter spin the way the real game allows. The power meters and putting grids also are somewhat of a mystery and don't seem to be designed to let the player really know exact measurements. This may be on purpose, but still this is a sim and not real life, so we need some way to benchmark our swings and fades, etc...

It needs a player history system so I can go back and review my previous rounds, and of course, it needs more courses. I hope most of all, the developers are going to be able to make a deal with the PGA for rights to their courses and tournament play, but even if it remains simply a non-PGA golf simulation, that's fine on its own. If you want to learn the game and progress without getting bored, I think this will be a good title someday. I hope it is sooner than later.

added: May 5, 2016:

As I said in my earlier review, the heart of a good game was there, and I was hoping Perfect Parrellel was working hard on the serious issues in the engine. I'm wondering if the makers of this game couldn't care less about the gamers in Steam and are more interested in the Golf Simulators out there than can use this software. Because right now, us gamers are getting no love from the game.

A few points for the developers, which I hope read this:

...The putting mechinism is simply awful. Damn near unplayable. It's swing mechanics are inconsistent and clunky. There is no context to the power of the swing and they give little to no credible way to read the greens. It needs serious re-tooling before this game can be considered top notch.

...there is no way to craft shots and the chipping and pitching is abysmal and inconsitent. You'll never hit the same shot twice in the same conditions.

...the swing meter, which is the only way most gamers are going to play this game, is baffling and inconsistent. it gives no power context either but even if it did, you can never re-create shots no matter how hard you try.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The key to deciding whether you should buy this game is whether you like golf.  Real life golf is frustrating, but very rewarding if you can achieve success, and to do that, it takes some work.  This game is the same way, you have to put some time in to get some success - but it can be fun on the way due to the high quality courses available upon which to play.  I have been pleasantly surprised by the quailty of the courses, both the ones supplied by default in the game, and the user designed courses which so far have proven to be of as high a quality as the default courses.
My favorite method of play (swing type) is the newly implemented Real Time Swing - Motion Swing which is proving to be very immersive giving you the feeling that you are really on a golf course and not sitting in front of a computer.
Some of the new courses and swing type changes is stirring more interest in this game and there is quite a community of active players who hang out in the lobby for online multiplayer games.  There is also a site which offers weekly tournaments seemlessly integrated into the game with nearly 100 players signed up at the tour pro level (the one I play).  I do not know how many play in the other level tournaments, I suspect that it is 100s more.  There are currently no additional costs to fully participate in the game, courses, lobby or tournaments (although the tournament host does solicit donations on the website through a button).  Eventually there will be premium content for purchase (licensed courses, and accesories which will only be cosmetic and not give you an advantage in the game), but that content will not be necessary to enjoy the game.
There will be a program called course forge which will allow anyone who purchases this game to design beautiful course the same way that the original ones were developed.  The current crop of user developed courses were designed by beta testers of course forge.  Course forge will come out when the game exits Early Access, probably sometime this year (but don't quote me).

Pluses - gameplay is rich, not repetitive, due to realistic physics and variability
interest in the game is growing, lots of partners/opponents available
developer is active, listens to gamers suggestions and incorporates improvements
game works on multiple platforms including golf simulators

Minuses - game requires modern computer graphics power to enjoy smooth gameplay
players who want instant gratification may be disappointed with learning curve

My advice is to purchase this game while it is still in Early Access as it will surely be more than $20 when it is fully released.

I'm physically handicapped, so I need simply controlled games.  No fps's, fast rts's or sports games, just click and click some more.  This is perfect in that regard.  Unfortunately though, whie easy to play, the graphics are painfully dull and the ambiance needs work.  If you're going to stare at the screen at least make the textures detailed or the models more defined.  The default character golfer is pretty low poly, now whether that's a design decision because they're using Unity, I don't know, but I've seen higher poly assets in other games on the same platform.  There's not much in terms of default animation with the golfer either, not that he should scratch himself with the putter, but like other games, whn you're lining up a shot you move or adjust your positions from looking at the hole, crouching to line things up and then finally taking the shot.  The scenery as I said, the ambiance needs work.  Skies, clouds, birds, water, grass and shrubbery, all just sits with a simple state to move a bit.  Just small amounts of movement.  I'm not asking for somebody to throw a pie, but if it's going to be a pc game, put some graphical power behind it.  I maxed the graphics, but still, nohing cool besides maybe a lens flare, but lens flares aren't cool...so here we are.

Gameplay, yeah there's multiplayer and you can set up games with friends, but that's standard these days.  No silly side games or practice shooting in a range.  Just dive in and it's pretty shallow.

I bought this for a twenty but that's a bit much, had I known what to expect I'd say it's maybe worth a fiver.  I wouldn't mind a refund but I won't lie, it's easy to play and it'll be great when I'm drunk trying to kill time.  My standards tendt to lower.

I'd say save your money for a bigger studio release.  Maybe get this if you love golf but if you can play whatever you like, unlike myself with a physical disability, dear lord buy something where you can kill stuff and destroy monsters.  Do it...do it for those who can't...do it for me.

Before buying this game please make sure that you understand that this game is still pretty much in early access, and there will be bugs etc., so it’s far from perfect in its current state. However if you want to help in its development then this is the perfect time to buy it. This game as a golf sim has so much potential and can be very challenging if you turn all the aids off. There are patches been applied, but because it’s a small development team they are few and far between. The graphics leave much to be desired, considering its 2015, the graphics are reminiscent of a game released in the late 90’s, I am sure that will also be improved in time.
There are currently only a few limited courses, unlike TGC (The Golf Club, by HB Studios) there is no course creator, so there are no community submitted courses to play on, which is a real shame as it’s something that would attract more players to this game.  This game has been developed for PC and I think it’s due for release on the consoles too.
It's now been several months on since this game was released. Its had many patchs which has improved this game even more. The graphics are still retro, but there is talk of improving this soon. As far as golf sim's go, then there is nothing out there that gets close to it. The game play is really solid and improves with each patch released.
The introduction of AI and the horizontal swing meter has in my opinion improved this game even better. The AI still needs some tweaking, but it's great to play against the computer, and you can also adjust the AI's skill level.
As I've mentioned before this is the only true golf sim out there, so a lot of practice is required if you want to play this game well.
Is it worth the price?..Hell yes, if you love golf, then make sure you have this in your bag. The introduction of an editor will soon make this a better game to play....

reviewText: As a very long term user of the Links Golf Game I and many others have had to wait an age for a worthy replacement to appear. Underwhelming at best. Every chance it will improve down the road, but impossible to recommend at this stage, particularly to those with lower specced PCs.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Game still needs a lot of work.

Graphics are just OK with current settings looks like something out of the 90s.
No support for a controller yet only three click swings or an awkward mouse meter.
The golf club seems to have better graphics and a lot more features and controller support but also has it's problems.
Lack of commentary on the golf course, some maybe OK with this, but the sound over all is pretty meh
It is early access, and I think the game has a mediocre foundation, but there is a lot of improvement needed at this point.
In my honest opinion if you're looking for a golf game on PC I would go with The Golf Club option, but beware it has it's quarks too.
